headline: BBQ Country-Style Ribs
description: These country-style ribs are twice-baked until fall-apart tender. Seasoned with garlic, lemon, and BBQ sauce, these easy oven-baked ribs are so tasty.

video.description: These ribs bake up deliciously in the oven. Yum!
video.name: BBQ Country Style Ribs

name: BBQ Country-Style Ribs

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C).
Place ribs in a single layer in a shallow baking pan or roaster; salt if desired. Spread garlic on ribs, then arrange lemon slices on top.
Bake in the preheated oven until tender, about 2 hours. Drain any grease and liquid. Pour barbeque sauce over ribs.
Reduce oven temperature to 225 degrees F (110 degrees C) and cook ribs until sauce bakes into meat, about 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: The recipe DOES NOT say to cover - the video shows it but I missed that part :) I am covering for the last hour and hoping for the best.
Mmm Scrump-didli-licous OMG I love these fall apart mouth watering

Very good! I rubbed seasoned salt with onion salt and pepper. Covered with light coating of sweet baby rays, turned after 20-30 minutes then turned and coated again on other side. Then 15 more minutes. They were so luscious.

This is my new go to recipe. I have made these ribs twice. I didnt use fresh lemon or garlic because i prefer dry rub. Instead i used 1tsp each of garlic powder, onion powder, and lemon pepper plus 1/2tsp paprika, a few dashes of salt, pepper, and cayenne pepper. I also cooked for 3 hours on 250, took them out and drained them, added the BBQ sauce, put the foil back on, lowered the temp to 225, and cooked for 1 more hour. They were falling apart, so tender and juicy. The first time was just for my small family of 3. The second time I made for my family and my fiancee's coworkers so i tripled the recipe. They all LOVED these ribs. A crowd pleaser for sure!

This came out so moist and favorful! I adjusted the cooking to 21/2 hours initially because the ribs were very thick. The barbecue sauce I added some honey and fresh garlic and it was delish! Will definitely cook again. My family loved it.

The only way this recipe is 5 stars...is to put them on the grill afterwards. I also put a rub on them in the oven, the BBQ sauce I put on at the end on the grill. If you chose baby back ribs, do not cook them so long, maybe 45-1 hour, and cover tightly to keep moisture in.

I started a review and hit send too soon therefore the duplication. This recipe is 5 stars as written. I added enough water to just cover the bottom of the pan and added about 1/2 tsp. liquid smoke. I roasted covered at 300 for 2 hours. After draining and adding the barbecue sauce, I sprinkled with smoked paprika and roasted covered for 1 hour. Added a honey glaze and finished on the grill for about 5 minutes per side. This was a hit and although I made more than enough to have leftovers, there were none. These were so tender!!! Delish!

I pushed the heat to 325 and then, I murdered the ribs so to speak! Lol.. I take a pairing knife and start stabbing away to the point where my boyfriend says "hey, what'd they do to you"... cooked for 2hrs at 325 then unsealed, drained and covered with BBQ sauce to put back in covered for 20min and uncovered for 10min. They were so tender I could barely get them out of the pan without them falling apart!!

Baked another 45 minutes and they weren't quite done so we gave it another hour and they were perfect. Every time I try to make ribs, it's hit or miss and I think maybe now we've got a plan!

This was so easy and so good! Followed the recipe as written. I did add salt to the top of the ribs but next time I will also salt the bottom side. Draining off the fat made it so we didn't have to add extra BBQ sauce to our finished product. It had plenty of sauce! Very good!

Wish I’d read the reviews first, extremely dry, and followed recipe as is. I wondered how they would not dry out but thought maybe the super low temp made the difference. No, add a tray of water in oven. Disappointed.

Very easy recipe to follow. I don’t understand why people tweak a recipe and then report a review on their changes. I kept the ribs covered in foil for all of 20 minutes of the cooking time. I did not add any water and had plenty of liquid in the roaster pan after first bake. I did not feel the lemon flavor came through overly strong. Also confused why people refer to bones in their reviews. Country style pork ribs are boneless and cut from the shoulder or loin; if you are using bone-in ribs they are not the cut of meat this recipe calls for which may cause poor results. Mine were not falling apart but were very tender! Used sweet baby Rays BBQ sauce-yum!
Moist and delicious! Thanks for sharing!

My country style ribs were really lean (from Walmart, if you can believe it) so I should have covered them with foil for the first 2 hours. It took forever to get them tender and I will never use this particular method again. I knew they should have been covered but I thought I'd go by the recipe. Big mistake. Gave it 4 stars because I made some changes in cooking this. I had 2.5lbs pork ribs. Added 1 cup water with 3 tbsp lemon juice and diced garlic on top. Covered it with foil. You will have extra for the sauce, you can warm it up for those that want some dipping. Don't forget to check the internal temperature, preferably to hit 180. It was super delicious!!!

Country style ribs aren't all the same. They either are from the front or rear portion of the loin. The boneless ones are from the rear portion (most all the time). They don't need low and slow. Just cook them until 130º and let them rest. You can stove top them in a pan. Save yourself some time.
